title.text: UAIC at SemEval-2019 Task 3: Extracting Much from Little

abstractContent.text: In this paper, we present a system description for implementing a sentiment analysis agent capable of interpreting the state of an interlocutor engaged in short three message conversations.

abstractContent.text: We present the results and observations of our work and which parts could be further improved in the future.

introductionContent.text: It is hard to understand emotions in textual conversations in the absence of voice modulations and facial expressions).

In sentiment analysis task researchers work on different levels of sentiment analysis: document (when are considered single topics documents), sentence (when single sentences are classified as positive, negative or neutral), entity or aspect (which deal with finding the aspects in the text and then classifying in respective aspect).
Similar to sentiment analysis at sentence level, in last years tweets from Twitter were analyzed and classified,, and).
In the beginning, a binary classification was used, which linked opinions or opinions only to two classes: positive or negative.

Spam and a variety of languages on Twitter make the task of identifying opinions very difficult.
In SemEval 2019, in Task 3, EmoContext: Contextual Emotion Detection in Text, the organizers ask participants to classify users messages in one of four classes: Happy, Sad, Angry or Others.

introductionContent.text: These are given in the context of another two previous messages.
The textual dialogue is composed of short messages that appear to be from a chat conversation.
In such a context, the users express their thoughts and ideas in a compact way.
In this paper, we describe how we created one classifier to detect the sentiment of short messages such as tweets.
